captions.text:
Hi everybody, joey here again and welcome
back. So today I'm going to show you guys

a cheap and easy way to polish your aquarium
water. Now the benefits to polishing your

aquarium water are obvious. We all want crystal
clear water with no floating debris. This

project will allow you to accomplish just
that. So to accomplish this project you're

only going to need three things. You're going
to need a water bottle, you're going to need

a power head and you're also going to need
some polyester filling. Commonly known in

the aquarium hobby as filter floss. For a
water bottle, all you're really going to need

is one of the smaller sizes. Approximately
five hundred milliliters. You're also going

to need filter floss and this is where you
will save money. Typically speaking, you can

get filter floss at a pet store. Filter floss
is filter floss though. It's all 100% polyester.

So what I like to do instead is go to a local
Wal-Mart or fabric store and buy a large bag

of quilt batting. This will cost around five
dollars. This will last you months. All you

need to do is make sure it is 100% polyester
filling and it has no additives like mold

or mildew resistant additives. You will also
need a power head. Now the preferred brand

is the maxi jet power head. This is due to
its design. You don't have to get a maxi jet,

but one with this design will be ideal. You
can pick up a small power head for this project

for around ten to fifteen dollars in most
cases. So let's get started with the project

itself, and then we will move onto how and
why it works. So first of all you're going

to need your water bottle. You will want to
cut off the bottom of the bottle you don't

need the bottom; you just need the top half.
Cut it right around the bottom. It won't really

matter where you cut it as you just need enough
room for the filter floss and you will see

why in a moment. That's really the only step
you need to take. From there, it gets really

easy. The next step is to take your power
head. Now the maxi jet comes with a pre filter

on it that protects the impeller from debris.
The reason why we want to use a maxi jet brand

is very specific and simple. When you put
it on a bottle or a bottle end, it fits really

snug. It's not going to come off any time
soon. It's the perfect fit. The next step

is obviously putting the filter floss inside
of this bottle. Just like that. That's it.

It's very simple. So when we turn the power
head on once installed into an aquarium, obviously

it's going to work like a regular power head.
It's going to suck water in through the intake

and recycle it back to the aquarium through
the output. But now that we have this bottle

filled with filter floss it's going to have
to suck the water through this filter floss

before it can be pushed back out of the output.
So that's it. We just basically install it

into the tank and let it polish the aquarium.
When you're done, take the power head out

and remove the actual bottle. You can put
your power head right back in. The overall

cost is really just going to lie in the actual
power head that you will need to purchase

as well as the actual filter floss. The filter
floss itself is going to last you two to three

months or probably a lot more if this is all
you're using it for. The power head, you only

have to buy it once and like I said, it's
going to have multiple uses. You can use it

for a lot of different projects. So that's
it folks. I hope you enjoyed the video, I

want to thank you guys for watching and we'll
see you next time.

comments.text:
I have 2 turtles which are messy and i put this setup in my tank. great as 
a pre-filter, picks up most of the larger particles which helps the main 
filter. I am in Canada so the prices you are reffering to are off for me. 
the powerhead i got it for $31 including taxes and i got the very same 
filler bag for $14 at walmart. for the price i am pleased with it and the 
powerhead is multi purpose which is great! i got the 900 model, but the 
1200 would be better for more suction power.﻿

comments.text:
This will only take out the poop and stuff, when your fish food dissolves 
and creates the cloud of fine sediments, it will not be able to. Remove 
that out of the water trust me I have one, floss turns green from all the 
algae I scrub off. ﻿
comments.author: derek brian

comments.text:
This WILL take out cloudiness (especially if you use a liquid water 
clarifier with it). Also, if you've got a cloud from fish food, you're 
probably overfeeding. As far as algae, if the floss is turning green 
because it's sucking in loose algae that you've scrubbed off the tank, then 
it's doing its job. If the floss is turning green because algae is growing 
on it, you're leaving the thing in too long. This is a quick fix to be used 
for a few hours to regain clarity, not filter the aquarium.

comments.author: Frank Quintanilla

comments.text:
I have 2 tanks! 8 1/2 gallon and a 29 gallon! And I just bought a 55 Gallon 
2 hours ago, but it's not set up!

Anyways, the 8 1/2 Gallon is perfect! It has 13 fish in it and the PH is 
perfect, zero ammonia, zero nitrites and the water is super, super clear. 
And I don't do anything… It has been perfectly clear water since it 
completed it's cycle. Both tanks have lots of plants, the same plants. The 
same Substrate, etc. But the larger one always has a slight cloudiness to 
it. The PH is 6.8, the Ammonia is zero and Zero nitrites. And the Nitrates 
are in the safe zone… oh and hardness is the same on both tanks. ON the 
small tank I have a cheap Tetra 10i filter. ON the larger I have a better 
filter with a bio wheel on it. Not sure why one tank is clear and the other 
is not. 

I am going to do this filter in addition to my filter and see what happens…
Thanks again Joey!! ﻿

comments.text:

a process of elimination and found that my air bubbles were foaming up and

having a bit of a panic attack :) Peace out! BTW still have the polisher in

comments.author: Cichlid Rasta

comments.text:
If a small mechanical filter was able to over take your biological filter, 
the original biological filter was simply undersized for your aquarium. 
If your LFS recommends chemicals to deal with the nitrogen cycle, i highly 
recommend changing LFS. 
The reason for you having issues was your original filter was too small to 
be your primary source of biological filtration. When you added a more 
powerful mechanical filter, the bacteria established faster on it. You 
changing it so often and using it so often, crashed the original filter. 

It doesn't matter how clean you aquarium is... bacteria is only present in 
numbers that the ammonia source(fish) allow it to be. Look at my tanks 
where i keep bare tanks.. squeaky clean, bare tanks. I keep stingrays, 
asian arowana, and breed discus in tanks like this, as my bacteria is 
contained within the biological filter. The bacteria lives in the filter as 
i give it no choice to live anywhere else. 
This not only proves, but it is obvious that the horrible saying of "your 
tank cant be too clean" is ridiculous. It is in fact, your filter that can 
not be too clean. You do not want to destroy the bacteria in the filter... 
which is why we only rince the biological media in tank water and not full 
clean it.
comments.author: The king of DIY
